questions.text:
A Forensic Expert is called to a crime scene where a potential sexual assault is suspected. The sheets from the scene do not visually reveal any obvious stains, but the pathologist knows that certain types of illumination can reveal traces of biological fluids that are not visible to the naked eye. They must choose the most appropriate method to detect these potential seminal stains for further analysis.

 

Question: Which type of light should the Forensic Expert use to visualize invisible or faint seminal stains at the crime scene?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) UV light.

 

Option A:

 

Seminal Fluid Examination –

 

  1. Physical Examination - Seminal stains when dry have a greyish-white or yellow-grey color and show an irregular, map-like outline. The cloth is stiffened as if starched. A fresh stain on a non-absorbent material appears translucent.

 

UV light

 

Seminal stains, which may not be visible to the naked eye, will fluoresce under ultraviolet (UV) light.

 

This is a common and effective method used in forensic investigations to detect biological fluids, including semen, which may contain crucial DNA evidence. It is masked by blood and disappears if the stain is soaked in water.

 

 

 

  1. Chemical Examination - Walker test (acid phosphatase test), Barberio test, Florence test, creatinine phosphokinase test, chromatography, immunological methods.

 

  1. Microscopic Examination - (confirmatory test) - stains like Christmas tree stain (MC), Baenchi stain, Giemsa, papanicolaou, and methylene blue are used to stain spermatozoa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Infrared light is not typically used for visualizing seminal stains as it does not cause the required fluorescence for detection.

 

Option C. Not used in forensic investigations for the visualization of stains.

 

Option D. Red light does not have the properties to make seminal stains visible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminal fluid examination - (Physical examination) dry seminal stains are grayish white in color and under UV light show bluish-white fluorescence due to presence of choline."

 

Reference - Reddy 33/e. Pg 418

choices.text: Acid phosphatase test

questions.text: A 48-year-old forensic examiner is presented with a set of preserved clothing articles from a case that is 4 months old. Suspicion arises regarding the presence of aged seminal stains on the fabric. To establish the presence of semen, especially considering the potential degradation of the sample over time, which of the following biochemical tests should the examiner prioritize to yield reliable results?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine phosphokinase test

 

Option D:

 

Spermatozoa contain a high concentration of Creatine Phosphokinase (CPK), which is more than double, than found in any other body fluid. Normal seminal fluid contains 385 to 1400 units of CPK/ml. Levels over 400 are almost diagnostic of seminal stains. The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains of six months, making it an effective tool for confirming the presence of semen in stains.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase test is useful for recent stains as concentration in excess of hundred Bodansky units with or without s indicate that ejaculation occurred within twelve hours of examination.  The concentration of acid phosphatase gradually falls with time in vaginal secretions, and positive reactions are found for periods of 36 hours, with gradual disappearance in 72 hours, but is little changed if the body is refrigerated.

 

The prostatic secretion element of seminal fluid contains 500 to 1000 times greater acid phosphatase than any other body fluid.

 

Option B. Barbario test detects spermine from the prostate in the seminal fluid, which is characterized by the formation of yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals (spermine picrate)  when treated with picric acid. It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable.

 

 

Option C. Florence test is indicative of the presence of choline from seminal vesicles and results in dark brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide upon treatment with Florence reagent. It is a presumptive test for seminal stain, not very reliable.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)
  • Acid phosphatase test—Conclusive test in absence of demonstrable sperm or aspermia cases
  • Creatine phosphokinase—helpful in old seminal stain (6 months)

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 435; Pics from Book “Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” by Gautam Biswas- Chapter Seminal Stains and Other Biological Samples

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was present to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty walking and pain around the anus. His guardian suspects he may have been a victim of sexual abuse. During the examination, a forensic expert performs a microchemical test on a sample collected from the perianal area. The presence of yellow, needle-shaped crystals is observed under the microscope. Which test was most likely conducted to obtain this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio’s Test

 

Option A:

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Barberio’s test –

 

Reagent: Picric Acid;  

 

Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland) Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Florence test -

 

Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O

 

Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)

 

Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test

 

Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid

 

Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride

 

Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals.

 

 

Option D. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test

 

Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose

 

Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

  • Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 434; Parikh 7th/e p. 7.26, 7.27; S.K. Singhal 4th/e p. 162-164

 

Pics from Book “Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” by Gautam Biswas- Chapter Seminal Stains and Other Biological Samples

questions.text: A woman brings her child to a counselor seeking assistance to establish paternity for legal purposes. The counselor suggests the most definitive and scientifically accurate method for determining biological paternity. Which of the following methods should be utilized?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DNA fingerprinting.

 

DNA fingerprinting, also known as DNA profiling, is the most reliable and precise method for determining paternity. It compares the DNA sequences between the child and the alleged father to look for evidence of inheritance. High-resolution DNA tests can determine paternity with a probability greater than 99.9%.

 

There are two methods of DNA analysis in common use:

 

  1. RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphism)
  2. PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While blood type can be used to exclude paternity in cases where the child possesses a blood type incompatible with the alleged father, it cannot definitively prove paternity due to the limited number of blood types and the possibility of multiple individuals sharing the same blood group.

 

Medicolegal Aspects of Blood Groups: Principles:

 

  1. A blood group antigen cannot appear in a child, unless present in one or another parent.
  2. If an individual is homozygous for a blood group factor, it must appear in the blood of all his children.
  3. If a child is homozygous for a blood group factor, the gene for the same must have been inherited by it from each of its parents.
  4. The blood group characters are peculiar to the individual and are unchanged throughout life.

 

Option B. Fingerprints are unique to every individual and do not demonstrate genetic relations.

 

Option C. Reliance on physical resemblance is highly subjective and not a definitive method for paternity testing, as phenotypic traits can be influenced by various genetic and environmental factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA fingerprinting as the gold standard for establishing paternity due to its high specificity and accuracy in comparing genetic material between individuals.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 459

questions.text: In the legal context of determining paternity, a clinician is tasked with obtaining a blood sample from an infant for DNA testing. To ensure the validity and safety of the sample for genetic analysis, what is the recommended minimum age at which a blood sample can be taken from an infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 months.

 

Explanation:

 

For paternity testing, it is recommended to collect blood samples from an infant at a minimum age of 6 months (but not less than 2 months). This recommendation considers the infant's developing immune system and the volume of blood that can be safely drawn. Prior to this age, the presence of maternal antibodies and the risk of anemia from blood draws are of concern.

 

One ml of blood should be obtained by a heel or ear prick, or venepuncture into a plain tube. The testing of the mother, child and putative father, i.e., the man whose potential paternity is under investigation, should be done in the same laboratory, by the same person, on the same day, and using the same batch of reagents and antisera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate age for blood sample collection from an infant for paternity testing is 6 months, to minimize health risks and potential interference from maternal antibodies.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 458

questions.text: During a forensic pathology rotation, a medical resident is tasked with confirming the presence of hemoglobin in a blood sample from an old crime scene. The sample is degraded, and the resident must choose a test that yields specific microscopic findings to ensure the accuracy of the result. Which test should the resident utilize to observe the characteristic pink feathery crystals that confirm the presence of hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takayama test

 

Option A:

 

Hemochromogen (Takayama) test

 

Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose

 

Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

It can be carried out on a small stain quantity, is effective on aged stains and is more dependable.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test

 

Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid

 

Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride

 

Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Option C. Barberio’s test -

 

Reagent: Picric Acid.  

 

Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)

 

Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

 

Option D. Xanthoproteic test -

 

The xanthoproteic reaction is a method that can be used to detect the presence of protein soluble in a solution, using concentrated nitric acid. The test gives a positive result in amino acids carrying aromatic groups (phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan) and forms a yellow-colored product known as Xantho protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

  • Teichmann’s - Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Takayama test - Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

  • Florence test—For choline (dark brown rhombic crystals)
  • Barberio test— detects spermine (yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 451; Pics from Book “Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology” by Gautam Biswas- Chapter Seminal Stains and Other Biological Samples

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is found unresponsive in his apartment with multiple bloodstains on his clothing. The first responders to the scene need to determine whether the bloodstains are recent or if some might have been present for a longer period. Which method should the forensic team use to confirm the presence of blood in both the recent and older stains on the clothing?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spectroscopic test

 

Option D:

 

The spectroscopic method is the most delicate and reliable test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains (can provide information about the age of the stains). Less than 0.1 mg of blood is sufficient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Luminol test: This is a presumptive test that can detect trace amounts of blood by producing a chemiluminescent glow. It is sensitive but not specific for blood, and it doesn't provide information about the age of the stain.

 

Option B. Benzidine test: It's an older test that is no longer used due to its potential to cause cancer. It was a color test that would turn blue in the presence of blood. It is also a presumptive test, sensitive but not specific.

 

Option C. O-tolidine test: This is another color test used for presumptive identification of blood. Like the Benzidine test, it is not as specific or informative regarding the age of the bloodstains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood stains can be identified by following tests - 

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 451

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is involved in a custody dispute and undergoes a forensic evaluation to establish the paternity of her child. The forensic scientist plans to use a bodily fluid for ABO blood typing, as the child is suspected to have inherited the secretor status from the parents. Which of the following bodily fluids is least likely to be suitable for ABO blood group determination in secretors?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF).

 

Option D:

 

In individuals known as secretors, their ABO blood group antigens are found in body fluids such as sweat, saliva, semen, urine, feaces, nasal secretions and tears. In the tissues they appear in a lipoidal form. In about 80 percent of the people, they appear in a water-soluble form, and can be demonstrated in all the body fluids except the cerebrospinal fluid. Secretors are individuals who secrete their blood group antigens into bodily fluids.

 

Persons who possess only the lipoidal form are known as 'non-secretors', while those who possess water-soluble form are known as 'secretors'.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tears - Secretors can have ABO antigens present in their tears.

 

Option B. Saliva - A common sample used for ABO typing in secretors as it often contains blood group antigens.

 

Option C. Semen - Like saliva, semen can also be used for ABO blood group determination in secretors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In secretors, ABO blood group antigens can be identified in various bodily fluids such as sweat, saliva, semen, urine, feaces, nasal secretions and tears, but not typically in cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Reference - Reddy 33/e. Pg 455

choices.text: Acid phosphatase test

questions.text: A rape victim is examined in a hospital and a specimen from her vagina is subjected to staining by 10% HCl, potassium iodide, iodine, and water. Dark brown rhombic shaped crystals appear immediately. Which test was done?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Florence test

 

Option B:

 

Crystal formation occurs in microchemical tests which are seen under the microscope. Out of all the options provided, barberio and florence are microchemical tests. The reagent in the question (HCl, potassium iodide, iodine) is for florence test. In barberio test the reagent is picric acid.

 

Florence test:

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

Note - Tests for seminal stains

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acid phosphatase test (quantitative): Finding a significantly elevated acid phosphatase level is consistent with the presence of semen. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase level of 340–360 Bodansky units/ml. A value of > 100 Bodansky units with/without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within 12 h of examination.

Level decreases with time after intercourse, and there is little chance of identifying it after 48 h. Isoenzymes can be detected using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis followed by staining with MUP reagent which can distinguish the acid phosphatase present in other substances.

 

Option C. Barberio’s test:

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

Option D. Creatine Phosphokinase test - Spermatozoa contain a high concentration of creatine phosphokinase, which is more than double than that found in any other body fluid. Values > 400 units/ml are diagnostic of seminal stains. The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains. The test will be negative in case of aspermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Florence test - Reagent is KI + I2 + H2O and show Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide.

 

Note - Using the three tests together (acid phosphatase, PSA, and spermatozoa detection) the presence of semen can be conclusively determined in vaginal swabs of the sexual assault victims.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 434; Parikh 7th/e p. 7.26, 7.27; S.K. Singhal 4th/e p. 162-164
